item.title: audile technique
item.description: audile technique A concept from !Jonathan Sterne (as cited in @BlueV2017) which describes the practices of listening based in science and reason, encouraging that what is heard be rationalized.

item.title: Black fungibility
item.description: Black fungibility The notion that not only are Black bodies commodified, but that they are fungible‚Äîentirely exchangeable with one another. This lives zero room for any Black individuality or interiority.

item.title: commodified anger
item.description: commodified anger A form of anger which is projected on to the Black body, as the Black body stands as site of excess and lack of affect (@Palmer2017).

item.title: consumerism often relies on white fascination with Black bodies
item.description: consumerism often relies on white fascination with Black bodies White fascination with Black bodies and culture stems from the history of blackface minstrelsy, which was one of America‚Äôs first widely-popular entertainment forms ( @BlueV2017).

item.title: consumers want to feel victorious
item.description: consumers want to feel victorious A claim from @BlueV2017 who considers the use of Black resistance as a marketing tactic. Since neutral and unmarked subjects are always signified as white, this demonstrates how Black resistance is appropriated by white consumers who project themselves into the victory of resistance.

item.title: listening as active and hearing as passive
item.description: listening as active and hearing as passive !Tom Rice (as cited in @BlueV2017) differentiates listening as an active engagement with sound and hearing as the experience of sound which one may not necessarily choose.

item.title: Must resistance be active?
item.description: Must resistance be active? A question arising from @BlueV2017’s differentiation between resistance vs existence. How does the differentiation between resistance and existence shift when considering the resistance inherent in a politics of refusal?

item.title: noise is a form of othered sound
item.description: noise is a form of othered sound !Mack Hagood, as cited in @BlueV2017, explores the problematization of noise as an impact of individualism in the neoliberal era, where sounds which are not personally chosen become constructed as the noise of the other.

item.title: politics of recognition
item.description: politics of recognition A politics which pushes for recognition as an anti-oppressive method. Often linked with representational politics. These politics have been critiqued as asking the oppressors to include the oppressed in their paradigm‚Äîan effort which espouses the tolerance of difference rather than any foundational change (see theory of change).

item.title: politics of refusal
item.description: politics of refusal A political positioning which refuses to deal in the dominant political structure due to its inability to address this position.

item.title: racial performativity
item.description: racial performativity Relying of @Austin1962’s speech act theory of performativity, @Munoz2012 (pp. 678‚Äì679) uses racial performativity to describe race as a political doing which has impacts such as the recognition of racial belonging and divergence in the world.

item.title: radical self-possession
item.description: radical self-possession A term from !Jacqui Alexander and used by @Cvetkovich2012 to describe form of sovereignty which includes feelings and sensory experience.

item.title: resistance vs existence
item.description: resistance vs existence @BlueV2017 argues that if Black subjects are considered disadvantaged, disempowered, and oppressed, all forms of Black innovation necessarily become understood through a lens of resistance.

item.description: sound is always filtered through aspects of human subjectivity The ways that sound is heard and made meaningful is never separate from sociality.

item.title: sound is political
item.description: sound is political @BlueV2017 shoes two ways that power rests with those who control sound: who gets to make what sounds where is determined by social norms and legislation (see also the way that sound is always filtered through aspects of human subjectivity and how noise is a form of othered sound) forms of authority use sound as a weapon, deterrent, and announcement of authority The politics of sound are embedded in a individualist philosophy which positions sound as against peace and individual rights.
